Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of baby with its head in a hood. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis terracottas workshop that was operational from the 3rd to the 2nd century BC and possibly later. A good, but unprovenanced parallel in the Louvre (Dunand no.784) is dated to the Roman period. Similar baby figure found on a lamp from Naukratis at the British Museum (Bailey Lamp Q614, GR 1888,0601.148) dated 1st century BC. Gutch dates this example 150BC to 250AD (Hogarth 1899, pl. 13.177). Another good parallel from Naukratis is in Bolton Museum (1886.31.29). Dunand, F. 1990, Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte, Paris. Hogarth, D. G., Edgar, C.C. 1899, “Excavations at Naukratis”, ABSA 5, 26-46.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 92, no. 177, pl. XIII, no. 177)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.230) (Phase 1)
